Actor Jon Hamm completed a 30-day rehab program for alcohol addiction at Silver Hill Hospital in Connecticut. His representatives requested privacy, and the news comes shortly before the final season of "Mad Men" premieres.

Creflo Dollar seeks $60 million from 200,000 donors to buy a $65 million Gulfstream G650 jet for his ministry, claiming the new aircraft will help spread the gospel more effectively after experiencing issues with his current aging plane.

A study reveals Neanderthals were more advanced than previously thought, having crafted jewelry from eagle talons and potentially possessing sophisticated hunting skills, challenging the stereotype of them as primitive beings.

Two University of Oklahoma students, Parker Rice and Levi Pettit, were expelled for leading a racist chant in a fraternity video. Both apologized, with their families defending their character while condemning their actions as a terrible mistake.

An 11-year-old boy dressed as Christian Grey from "Fifty Shades of Grey" for World Book Day, causing controversy. His mother defended the costume, arguing it was humorous, while the school modified his outfit and allowed him to participate.

A Washington state trooper ticketed a driver using a Jonathan Goldsmith cardboard cutout to illegally use the HOV lane. The trooper, amused by the creative attempt, issued a $124 ticket while noting the driver was laughing during the encounter.

Severe storms hit Oklahoma, killing one person and injuring about two dozen. A tornado devastated a mobile home park near Tulsa, destroying dozens of trailers. Governor Mary Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties after widespread damage.

The article argues that Republican-controlled Congress should prioritize reversing defense budget cuts from the Obama administration, warning that reduced military spending weakens national security and emboldens adversaries. They propose increasing defense funding to address growing global threats and support military readiness.

A massive winter storm spans 2,000 miles, affecting 94 million people with snow, ice, and potential flooding. Dallas and other areas experience significant disruptions, with airport cancellations, snow emergencies, and challenging weather conditions across multiple states.

In Detroit, a bailiff discovered two children's bodies in a freezer during an eviction. The children's mother was arrested on child abuse charges. The boy was 11, the girl 14. Two older children were placed in protective custody.

Russian President Vladimir Putin reappeared in public after a 10-day absence, meeting with Kyrgyz President Atambayev in St. Petersburg. His unexplained disappearance sparked rumors about his health and power, which he dismissed with humor, saying "It would be boring without gossip."

Scientists suggest Jupiter's early migration through the inner solar system destroyed existing "super-Earths" by sweeping planetesimals into the sun, clearing the way for the formation of smaller terrestrial planets like Earth, Mercury, Venus, and Mars.

Two U.S. Army National Guard members were arrested for allegedly plotting to support ISIS, including plans to attack a military installation in Illinois. One cousin planned to travel to join ISIS, while the other intended to carry out a domestic attack.

Jeremy Clarkson, a Top Gear presenter, sparked controversy in Argentina with a Porsche license plate seemingly referencing the Falklands War. The crew was attacked by locals, and Clarkson has a history of making offensive comments that have drawn criticism and suspension from the BBC.

A new book, "Becoming Steve Jobs," offers a more compassionate portrayal of the Apple co-founder, contrasting with Walter Isaacson's earlier biography. Apple executives praise the new book, criticizing Isaacson's version as unfairly portraying Jobs as selfish and egotistical.

Actress Taraji P. Henson apologized to Glendale Police after falsely claiming her son was racially profiled during a traffic stop. Dash cam footage contradicted her allegations, showing her son was stopped for traffic violation and found with marijuana.

The article addresses six viewer questions about the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash, covering topics like descent rate, technological prevention, cockpit cameras, potential hacking, impact explosion, and pilot drug screening, providing expert insights into the mysterious and tragic incident.

Wales defeated Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualification, with Gareth Bale scoring twice and setting up Aaron Ramsey's goal. The victory put Wales at the top of their group, while Italy and Czech Republic narrowly avoided defeats in their matches.

Horse safaris in South Africa offer a unique way to explore game reserves, using ex-racehorses trained to navigate wildlife encounters. Guided by experienced owners, riders can get close to animals like lions, zebras, and giraffes while enjoying a thrilling, immersive experience.

Nigerian military claims to have retaken Gwoza, Boko Haram's former "caliphate" headquarters, just before national elections. The victory comes amid ongoing efforts to combat the terrorist group's violence in northeastern Nigeria.

Nigeria's presidential election faces tension as protesters in Rivers state allege vote rigging, with fears of widespread violence. Both candidates, Goodluck Jonathan and Muhammedu Buhari, call for calm as results are being counted, hoping to avoid a repeat of the 2011 post-election unrest.

Italy's high court definitively cleared Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito of Meredith Kercher's murder. The Kercher family is disappointed, and both Knox and Sollecito may potentially sue Italy for false imprisonment, though legal challenges remain complex.

Tropical Cyclone Pam devastated Vanuatu, destroying 90% of houses in Port Vila, killing 11 people, and leaving thousands homeless. The storm's massive destruction has prompted international aid efforts, with the full extent of damage still unknown.

The article discusses a growing bipartisan movement for criminal justice reform, with conservatives and progressives finding common ground on reducing mass incarceration, protecting individual liberties, and providing second chances to those who have been imprisoned.

Zayn Malik, 22, is leaving One Direction after five years, shocking fans worldwide. The band will continue as a four-piece, with their world tour and fifth album still planned. Spotify reported a massive spike in the band's music streams following the announcement.

Zayn Malik left One Direction, apologizing to fans and explaining he couldn't continue with the band. He feels more in control now, is on good terms with the other members, and is working on a solo project. The band will continue as a foursome.

The first trailer for "SPECTRE" reveals James Bond's new mission, featuring Daniel Craig infiltrating a global terrorist organization after receiving a cryptic message from his past. The trailer hints at a complex plot involving personal secrets and shadowy figures.

Vladimir Putin's sudden disappearance sparked widespread speculation about his health and whereabouts, highlighting Russia's authoritarian system and the uncertainty surrounding potential leadership succession. Social media buzzed with rumors, while the Kremlin attempted to quash speculation about Putin's condition.

Police found no substantive evidence supporting a University of Virginia student's rape allegation published in Rolling Stone. The magazine later acknowledged discrepancies in the story and apologized for not verifying the account with the accused parties.

Kylie Minogue, a multi-talented Australian star, will perform a 90-minute show at the Dubai World Cup, a prestigious horse racing event with $30 million in prize money, marking an exciting milestone in her career.

Thousands of Tunisians marched in Tunis to protest terrorism after a museum attack that killed over 20 people. World leaders joined the demonstration, and the Prime Minister announced the killing of the alleged attack mastermind, Khaled Shayeb.

Michael Ibsen, a descendant of Richard III, crafted a coffin for the king's remains, discovered under a Leicester car park in 2012. The reburial ceremony aims to honor the monarch and challenge historical perceptions of his character.

Senator Harry Reid's retirement paves the way for Chuck Schumer to become Senate Democratic leader. Schumer, a media-savvy politician from New York, is well-positioned to lead the party with his political skills, fundraising ability, and strategic vision for Democrats.

During spring break in Panama City Beach, a shooting wounded seven college-age people. David Jarmichael Daniels was arrested on seven counts of attempted murder. The city council discussed violence and increased beach enforcement, but did not ban alcohol.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people aboard. The plane descended for eight minutes before crashing near Digne-les-Bains. Investigators found one black box and are working to determine the cause of the crash.

AMC's "The Walking Dead" companion series is titled "Fear The Walking Dead," a prequel set in Los Angeles during the zombie outbreak's early stages. Starring Cliff Curtis, Kim Dickens, and others, it will premiere in late summer 2015.

Kentucky dominated West Virginia 78-39, advancing to the Elite Eight with a historic 37-0 record. Notre Dame, Wisconsin, and Arizona also won their games, setting up exciting matchups in the tournament's next round.

Lewis Hamilton secured pole position at the Malaysian Grand Prix in challenging, rainy conditions, beating Sebastian Vettel and Nico Rosberg. Young driver Max Verstappen impressed by qualifying sixth, while Hamilton aims to build on his Australian Grand Prix win.

Yemen's President Hadi, backed by a Saudi-led Arab coalition, is fighting Houthi rebels who took over the capital. Airstrikes target Houthi positions, with potential ground invasion possible. The conflict involves Sunni-Shiite tensions and regional power struggles, with civilian casualties reported.

A commuter train collided with a car near USC, causing the train to derail. Twenty-one people were injured, with 10 hospitalized, including two in critical or grave condition. The incident may impact traffic for a nearby soccer game.

The article describes the tragic Germanwings Flight 9525 crash, where co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane into the Alps, killing all 150 people on board. The passengers experienced a gradual descent and likely heard frantic attempts by the pilot to re-enter the cockpit before the fatal impact.

Jeremy Clarkson, suspended from "Top Gear" for allegedly hitting a producer, received nearly 1 million signatures supporting his reinstatement. A supporter drove a tank to BBC headquarters with the petition, while Clarkson expressed uncertainty about his future with the show.

A community in Montoursville, Pennsylvania shares their experience of losing 16 students and five chaperones in a plane crash, offering support and empathy to Haltern am See, Germany, after their own tragic Germanwings Flight 9525 loss.

The article discusses how the Germanwings pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed a plane, challenging the perception of pilots as infallible professionals. It argues that pilots are human, with flaws and unpredictable behaviors, and their actions can sometimes be incomprehensible.

The article describes the March 30, 2015 CNN Student News episode, which covers Nigerian elections, an astronaut's mission to the International Space Station, and an invention using sound waves to extinguish fires. It also provides information about accessing the show's transcript and participating in the Roll Call.

Manchester United defeated Tottenham 3-0, with goals from Fellaini, Carrick, and Rooney. The win boosted United's Champions League qualification hopes while damaging Tottenham's. Chelsea drew 1-1 with Southampton, maintaining their league lead. Everton won 3-0 against Newcastle, and Real Madrid beat Levante 2-0.

Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's founding prime minister, was honored in a state funeral attended by global leaders. Thousands mourned his passing, celebrating his role in transforming Singapore from a poor trading post to a wealthy financial center, despite criticism of his authoritarian approach.

Houthi rebels seized an airport in Taiz, Yemen, escalating tensions as the country nears civil war. The UN Security Council calls for peaceful dialogue, while the president's resignation remains contested and terror groups potentially exploit the chaos.

A University of Oklahoma fraternity house mother was filmed using a racial slur while singing along to a rap song. Despite the controversial video, two black alumni defended her, saying she is not racist and was caught up in the moment.

A rare 475-pound leatherback sea turtle, named Yawkey, was rescued by the South Carolina Aquarium after washing up on a beach. The juvenile turtle is being treated and is expected to be released back into the ocean within days.

ISIS claimed responsibility for a terrorist attack at the Bardo Museum in Tunis, killing 23 people, mostly foreign tourists. The attack targeted Tunisia's tourism industry and was seen as a challenge to the country's democratic success after the Arab Spring.

Nuclear talks between world powers and Iran continue in Lausanne, with key issues unresolved, including sanctions lifting and nuclear research limits. Negotiations are intense, with a Tuesday deadline approaching, and Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu expressing deep concerns about the potential agreement.

A jury found Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams guilty of copyright infringement for their hit song "Blurred Lines," which copied elements from Marvin Gaye's "Got to Give It Up." They were ordered to pay $7.4 million in damages.

The article discusses global urbanization, highlighting that over 54% of the world's population now lives in cities. It focuses on African urban centers, ranking them based on infrastructure, human capital, and economic potential, with both North and sub-Saharan cities showing promising growth.

Trevor Noah, 31, will succeed Jon Stewart as host of "The Daily Show" after three appearances on the show. Stewart endorsed Noah, calling him a "tremendous comic and talent." Noah expressed excitement and humility about taking over the popular satirical news program.

In Lagos, Nigeria, "free readers" gather around newspaper vendors to read and discuss headlines without buying papers. Despite potential lost sales, vendors like John Mgbachi welcome these passionate readers, who come from diverse backgrounds and enjoy social interaction while staying informed.

India's Supreme Court struck down Section 66A of the Information Technology Act, ruling it unconstitutional and a threat to freedom of expression. The law had allowed authorities to arrest people for offensive or annoying social media posts.

Three Los Angeles residents were arrested for operating fake schools that allowed foreign students to stay in the U.S. illegally. The scheme involved collecting $6 million in tuition from about 1,500 students who never attended classes, with the defendants facing immigration fraud and money laundering charges.

Kate Middleton made her final public appearance before maternity leave, visiting the Stephen Lawrence Centre in London with Prince William. She is expecting her second child in mid-to-late April, following the birth of Prince George in 2013.

The article discusses the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash, where co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane, killing 150 people. It explores the psychological factors behind such actions, advocating for more rigorous pilot screening and highlighting the unpredictability of human behavior.

Sam Taylor-Johnson will not direct the "Fifty Shades" sequel due to creative differences with author E L James. The first film was successful, grossing over $550 million worldwide, but tensions arose over screenplay control for the next installment.

Arnold Palmer, 85, plans to hit the ceremonial opening tee shot at the Masters despite a shoulder injury from a fall. Though doctors won't let him swing a club yet, he remains determined to participate in the tradition he started in 2007.

Nuclear negotiations between Iran and P5+1 countries are progressing, with both sides expressing cautious optimism about reaching a deal on Iran's nuclear program before the March 31 deadline, despite remaining challenges and disagreements over sanctions and centrifuges.

The article discusses China's "left-behind children," millions of kids abandoned in rural areas while parents seek work in cities. These children face significant challenges, including mental health issues and lack of parental care, due to urbanization and restrictive household registration policies.

Afghan President Ashraf Ghani visits Washington amid potential peace talks with the Taliban. While negotiations face significant challenges, the U.S. should support creating conditions for future successful talks by slowing troop withdrawal and helping stabilize the Afghan government.

Iraqi forces, backed by Shia militias, have captured key areas in Tikrit, raising the Iraqi flag over the governorate and hospital. They've made progress after U.S.-led airstrikes, killing at least 26 ISIS militants while navigating through hundreds of improvised explosive devices.

Hillary Clinton faces another email controversy, using her familiar strategy of attacking accusers, waiting out media frenzy, and rallying her party's base. Despite past scandals, she remains resilient and determined to fight back against political opponents seeking to undermine her presidential campaign.

Swedish prosecutors seek to interview Julian Assange in London about 2010 sexual assault allegations, offering to take his DNA and questioning him at the Ecuadorian Embassy before statute of limitations expires in August 2015.

New Zealand defeated South Africa in a thrilling Cricket World Cup semifinal, with Grant Elliott hitting a decisive six off the penultimate ball. This marks New Zealand's first World Cup final appearance, setting up a potential showdown with Australia or India.

The article discusses the growing interest in Buddhism among young Chinese people, who are seeking spiritual meaning and stress relief in a rapidly changing society, despite challenges in fully embracing religious practices.

In North Sinai, an explosive-laden truck attacked an Egyptian security camp, killing one civilian and injuring 44 people, including 42 soldiers. The truck's driver was killed after guards shot at the vehicle. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

Al-Shabaab militants attacked government offices in Baidoa, Somalia, killing nine people, including four attackers. The assault involved a car bomb and gunfire, targeting the regional president's house. The group claimed responsibility, seeking to demonstrate relevance after recent military defeats.

Tennis star Eugenie Bouchard and pop singer Justin Bieber played doubles at a charity tennis event in California, with Bouchard praising Bieber's serve. They posed for photos at the Annual Desert Smash event, which supports Cancer for College scholarships.

The article discusses potential Israeli responses to an Iran nuclear deal, highlighting that a military strike would have severe diplomatic, strategic, and security consequences. Israel is more likely to pursue diplomatic criticism, maintain sanctions pressure, and monitor Iran's activities rather than launch a military attack.

Kenya is the world's third-largest flower exporter, with over 500,000 people employed in the industry. Located near Lake Naivasha, Kenyan flower farms produce high-quality roses, carnations, and summer flowers primarily for European markets, generating around $600 million annually.

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted SNL, performing in comedic sketches like a muscular Bambi and The Rock Obama. He then made a surprise appearance at Wrestlemania 31 with Ronda Rousey, entertaining fans and showcasing his wrestling roots.

The Vatican hosted 150 homeless people on a special tour, guided by Archbishop Krajewski. They visited the Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, and other significant sites, experiencing the Vatican's artistic heritage typically unseen by those in poverty.

The UK Supreme Court ruled that previously secret letters from Prince Charles to government officials must be made public, despite government resistance. The Guardian newspaper won a 10-year legal battle to release the correspondence, which may reveal Charles' potential political influence.

The article explores the challenges facing tigers in India, where human population growth and conflict threaten their survival. Despite challenges, India's tiger population has increased by 30%, making it the only country with a growing tiger population.

The article discusses Indiana's controversial Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), which critics argue could enable discrimination against LGBT individuals. The governor initially defended the law but later supported amending it. The article explores potential legislative fixes to prevent discrimination while maintaining religious freedom protections.

Jordan Spieth won the Valspar Championship in a three-way playoff, becoming the fourth player since 1940 to win twice on the PGA Tour before turning 22. He aims to challenge Rory McIlroy for the world No. 1 ranking and gain confidence heading into the major tournaments.

The article is about a CNN Student News episode on April 1, 2015, covering global events in Nigeria, Switzerland, and West Africa. It discusses U.S. wages, financial literacy, and potential uses of cyborg cockroaches. The page provides a transcript and a Roll Call section for school mentions.

Lewis Hamilton won the Australian Grand Prix, leading a Mercedes one-two finish. Sebastian Vettel took third for Ferrari. Only 11 cars finished the race, with Max Verstappen becoming the youngest F1 driver at 17. Arnold Schwarzenegger presented the post-race interviews.

Michael Douglas wrote about his son Dylan experiencing anti-Semitism while on vacation. He emphasized the importance of confronting such hatred and fighting against its spread, noting that anti-Semitism is a persistent problem that requires collective action.

Researchers discovered a 1,000-year-old Anglo-Saxon eye infection remedy that effectively kills up to 90% of MRSA bacteria in lab tests, challenging perceptions of medieval medical knowledge and potentially offering a new approach to antibiotic-resistant infections.

Netanyahu backtracked on his pre-election stance against a Palestinian state, but tensions remain high. Palestinians are skeptical and may seek UN recognition, while the US reassesses its relationship with Israel, emphasizing the need for a two-state solution.

The article discusses Indiana's controversial "religious freedom" law, which could allow businesses to refuse service to gay customers based on religious beliefs. The law has sparked intense debate, with supporters claiming religious protection and opponents arguing it enables discrimination.

The Fourth Plinth in London's Trafalgar Square features a new sculpture called "Gift Horse" by Hans Haacke. The skeletal horse with a Stock Exchange ticker symbolizes the connection between art, power, and commerce, continuing the project's tradition of provocative public art.

Adam West and Burt Ward plan to voice an animated Batman movie in 2016, marking the 50th anniversary of their 1960s TV series. Ward hinted at the project during a convention, with West confirming they will be involved in the animated feature.

Nuclear talks between Iran and world powers in Lausanne, Switzerland, have been extended by a day as negotiators work to resolve key issues on Iran's nuclear program, sanctions, and potential nuclear weapon development, with optimism but challenges remaining.

BBC Director-General Tony Hall received death threats after firing Jeremy Clarkson from "Top Gear" following an altercation with a producer. Police are investigating the email threat, which reportedly originated outside the UK.

Maria Shriver discusses the impact of Alzheimer's, particularly on women, and launches the Wipe Out Alzheimer's Challenge to raise awareness, fund research, and support those affected by the disease, inspired by the movie "Still Alice" and her personal experience with her father's diagnosis.

A Canadian tourist, Jennifer Karren, died after her inflatable tour boat collided with a whale near Cabo San Lucas, Mexico. Two others were injured during the incident. The boat was returning from a snorkel tour when the collision occurred.

A court in Ivory Coast sentenced former first lady Simone Gbagbo to 20 years in prison for her role in post-election violence in 2010 that killed over 3,000 people. Her husband, Laurent Gbagbo, faces similar charges at the International Criminal Court.

Rory McIlroy threw a 3-iron into a lake during a tournament at Trump's Doral course. Trump retrieved the club and returned it to McIlroy, who struggled in the final round. Dustin Johnson won the tournament, marking his comeback to the PGA Tour.
